You said:
how do I make changes to my github page before making it public? I thought there is a way to run it locally to see
ChatGPT said:

You’re right — you can definitely preview your GitHub Pages site locally before making it public. The way you do this depends a little on whether your site is plain HTML/CSS/JS or built with something like Jekyll (which GitHub Pages supports natively). Here’s the breakdown:

1. If it’s just static HTML/CSS/JS

You don’t need anything fancy. You can:

  • Simply open the index.html file in your browser, or

  • Run a lightweight local web server to mimic how GitHub Pages will serve it.

For example, if you have Python installed:

bash
# Python 3
python -m http.server 8000

Then open http://localhost:8000 in your browser.

2. If it’s a Jekyll site (Markdown, layouts, _config.yml)

GitHub Pages runs Jekyll under the hood. To preview locally:

  1. Install Ruby and Bundler.

  2. Install Jekyll:

    bash
    gem install jekyll bundler

  3. Navigate to your repo and run:

    bash
    bundle exec jekyll serve

    By default, it’ll serve at http://localhost:4000.

That way you’ll see the site exactly as GitHub Pages will build it.

3. Using GitHub’s official Docker container (optional, avoids installing Ruby locally)

If you don’t want to set up Ruby, you can run Jekyll in Docker:

bash
docker run --rm -v $(pwd):/srv/jekyll -p 4000:4000 jekyll/jekyll jekyll serve

4. Things to double-check before going public

  • Verify links are relative (so they work on GitHub Pages).

  • Make sure your _config.yml has the correct baseurl if you’re publishing under username.github.io/repo.

  • Test across different browsers to catch quirks.

👉 Do you know if your GitHub Pages project is a plain static site or a Jekyll-based one? That will decide whether you just need a simple server or the full Jekyll workflow.

You said:
it is a github site with many pages
ChatGPT said:

Got it. If it’s a “GitHub Pages site with many pages,” you’re almost certainly using Jekyll. Here’s the no-nonsense way to run it locally and catch issues before you flip it public.

How to preview your GitHub Pages site locally

1) Confirm it’s Jekyll

Check your repo. If you see _config.yml, _layouts/, _includes/, _posts/ (or other folders starting with _), it’s Jekyll.

2) Use the same build GitHub uses (recommended)

This ensures your local build matches GitHub’s production environment.

Gemfile (at repo root):

ruby
source "https://rubygems.org"
gem "github-pages", group: :jekyll_plugins

Then:

bash
# From repo root
bundle install
bundle exec jekyll serve

Open: http://localhost:4000

Handy flags:

bash
bundle exec jekyll serve --livereload --incremental --drafts --future

  • --livereload: auto-refresh on save

  • --incremental: faster rebuilds

  • --drafts, --future: preview posts not yet published

Windows tip: if native Ruby is painful, use WSL or the Docker option below.

3) If you don’t want Ruby installed (Docker)

bash
docker run --rm -v "$PWD":/srv/jekyll -p 4000:4000 jekyll/jekyll \
  bash -lc "bundle install && bundle exec jekyll serve --livereload"

4) Set url/baseurl correctly (common gotcha)

Open _config.yml:

  • User/Org site (username.github.io):

    yaml
    url: "https://username.github.io"
baseurl: ""

  • Project site (served at /myproject):

    yaml
    url: "https://username.github.io"
baseurl: "/myproject"

Use these helpers in templates so links work both locally and on GitHub:

liquid
<!-- Good: path-safe -->
<link rel="stylesheet" href="{{ '/assets/css/main.css' | relative_url }}">
<a href="{{ '/about/' | relative_url }}">About</a>

<!-- Better for full URLs when needed -->
{{ '/about/' | absolute_url }}

5) Link safely (avoid hardcoding)

  • Use {% link path/to/file.md %} for internal pages/files.

  • Use {% post_url 2025-01-01-my-post %} for posts.
    These break the build if the target is wrong—great for catching bad links locally.

6) Validate your build like CI would

Run:

bash
bundle exec jekyll build

This produces _site/ exactly like GitHub will. If it builds cleanly, you’re in good shape.

7) If your site is not Jekyll (pure static)

You can still preview locally with a simple server:

bash
# Python 3
python -m http.server 8000
# or Node
npx http-server .

Open: http://localhost:8000

8) Pre-launch checklist (worth 2 minutes)

  • Pages load with and without trailing slashes.

  • No absolute paths to /myproject unless you intend them (use relative_url).

  • Assets (CSS/JS/images) referenced via | relative_url.

  • Titles/SEO: set title, description, and lang in the layout; verify <title> changes per page.

  • 404 works: visit /nope locally and confirm your 404 page shows.

  • Run a quick link check (optional but helpful):

    bash
    # Install once
gem install html-proofer
# Check generated site
htmlproofer ./_site --check-external-hash --only-4xx

If you want, paste your _config.yml (redact anything sensitive) and the repo type (user/org vs project). I’ll tailor the exact url/baseurl and a starter layout snippet so your links and assets resolve perfectly both locally and on GitHub.

You said:
ok I am using jekyII, but on one page, I would like to show a list of pictures with some text next to it. can you give me the code to do it?
ChatGPT said:

Great—Jekyll makes this clean and reusable. Below are two solid options. Pick one and drop it into your site.

Option A — Quick, inline on a single page

Paste this into a page like gallery.md (or .html). It’s self-contained and responsive.

markdown
---
layout: default
title: Gallery
permalink: /gallery/
---

<style>
  .gallery-list { display: grid; grid-template-columns: 1fr; gap: 1.25rem; }
  .gallery-item { display: grid; grid-template-columns: 160px 1fr; gap: 1rem; align-items: start; }
  .gallery-item img { width: 100%; height: auto; border-radius: 0.5rem; display: block; }
  .gallery-item h3 { margin: 0 0 .25rem; font-size: 1.05rem; }
  .gallery-item p { margin: 0; color: #555; }
  @media (max-width: 640px) {
    .gallery-item { grid-template-columns: 1fr; }
  }
</style>

<div class="gallery-list">
  <article class="gallery-item">
    <img src="{{ '/assets/images/photo-1.jpg' | relative_url }}" alt="Describe photo 1" loading="lazy">
    <div>
      <h3>Caption or Title 1</h3>
      <p>Short descriptive text about this image. You can include <a href="#">links</a> too.</p>
    </div>
  </article>

  <article class="gallery-item">
    <img src="{{ '/assets/images/photo-2.jpg' | relative_url }}" alt="Describe photo 2" loading="lazy">
    <div>
      <h3>Caption or Title 2</h3>
      <p>Another description placed next to the image.</p>
    </div>
  </article>

  <!-- Duplicate <article> blocks as needed -->
</div>

Notes:

  • Uses relative_url so paths work both locally and on GitHub Pages.

  • Mobile stacks vertically; desktop shows image left, text right.

Option B — Data-driven (edit one YAML file, page builds itself)

Best if you have many items or want to reuse the layout later.

1) Create a data file: _data/gallery.yml

yaml
- image: /assets/images/photo-1.jpg
  alt: "Describe photo 1"
  title: "Caption or Title 1"
  text: "Short descriptive text about this image. You can include links."
  url: "https://example.com/more-info"   # optional

- image: /assets/images/photo-2.jpg
  alt: "Describe photo 2"
  title: "Caption or Title 2"
  text: "Another description placed next to the image."

2) Create the page: gallery.md

markdown
---
layout: default
title: Gallery
permalink: /gallery/
---

<style>
  .gallery-list { display: grid; grid-template-columns: 1fr; gap: 1.25rem; }
  .gallery-item { display: grid; grid-template-columns: 180px 1fr; gap: 1rem; align-items: start; }
  .gallery-item img { width: 100%; height: auto; border-radius: 0.5rem; display: block; }
  .gallery-item h3 { margin: 0 0 .25rem; font-size: 1.05rem; }
  .gallery-item p { margin: 0; color: #555; }
  @media (max-width: 640px) {
    .gallery-item { grid-template-columns: 1fr; }
  }
</style>

<div class="gallery-list">
  {% assign items = site.data.gallery %}
  {% for item in items %}
    <article class="gallery-item">
      <img src="{{ item.image | relative_url }}" alt="{{ item.alt | escape }}" loading="lazy">
      <div>
        {% if item.url %}
          <h3><a href="{{ item.url }}">{{ item.title }}</a></h3>
        {% else %}
          <h3>{{ item.title }}</h3>
        {% endif %}
        <p>{{ item.text }}</p>
      </div>
    </article>
  {% endfor %}
</div>

That’s it—add rows to _data/gallery.yml and the page updates automatically.

Optional refinements

  • Thumbnails vs originals: store smaller images in /assets/images/thumbs/ to keep the page snappy.

  • Lightbox: add a small script (e.g., [GLightbox] or similar) if you want click-to-zoom; wire it by wrapping the <img> with an <a href="full-size.jpg">.

  • Accessibility: keep alt concise but meaningful; don’t repeat the visible caption.

If you tell me your asset paths and whether you prefer grid or flex, I’ll tailor the CSS to your theme’s look and feel.

how does this part work? where should i put link?
ChatGPT said:

Good question. Let me break down how the link placement works in that Jekyll snippet.

Where the link goes

In Option B (data-driven) I gave you this conditional:

liquid
{% if item.url %}
  <h3><a href="{{ item.url }}">{{ item.title }}</a></h3>
{% else %}
  <h3>{{ item.title }}</h3>
{% endif %}

  • If you add a url property for that item in _data/gallery.yml, the title becomes a clickable link.

  • If you leave url out, the title is just plain text.

Example YAML entry:

yaml
- image: /assets/images/photo-1.jpg
  alt: "Describe photo 1"
  title: "Caption or Title 1"
  text: "Short descriptive text about this image."
  url: "https://example.com/more-info"   # link goes here

That would render as:

Caption or Title 1 (clickable → goes to https://example.com/more-info)
With your description text next to the image.

Alternative — make the whole image clickable

If you’d rather the image itself be the link, change this part:

liquid
<img src="{{ item.image | relative_url }}" alt="{{ item.alt | escape }}" loading="lazy">

to:

liquid
<a href="{{ item.url }}">
  <img src="{{ item.image | relative_url }}" alt="{{ item.alt | escape }}" loading="lazy">
</a>

Now clicking the picture takes you to the link.

Summary

  • Add the link in _data/gallery.yml as a url: field.

  • By default, the title text will be the link.

  • If you prefer, you can also wrap the <img> tag in <a> so the picture itself is clickable.

You said:
<a href="#">links</a> too.</p>
ChatGPT said:

Ah, I see what you’re pointing at — that little bit in my first example:

html
<p>Short descriptive text about this image. You can include <a href="#">links</a> too.</p>

That was just a placeholder to show you how you can drop a link into the descriptive text.

Here’s how it actually works:

  • <a href="..."> is the HTML anchor tag for a hyperlink.

  • The href attribute is where you put the URL (either a full URL or a relative path).

  • The text between <a> ... </a> is what shows up as clickable.

Example: external link

html
<p>This is my project — check it out on <a href="https://github.com/username/repo">GitHub</a>.</p>

That will render as:

This is my project — check it out on GitHub.

Example: internal link (to another Jekyll page)

If you want to link to another page within your site (say /about/):

html
<p>Read more on the <a href="{{ '/about/' | relative_url }}">About page</a>.</p>

That way the link works both locally and on GitHub Pages (because of relative_url).

So in that earlier snippet, you’d replace # with either:

  • a full external URL (https://example.com), or

  • a relative path inside your site ({{ '/page/' | relative_url }}).

You can absolutely run (and lint) your Jekyll-based GitHub Pages site locally before you publish. Here’s the straight path, plus the official docs.

Run it locally (matches GitHub Pages)

A) Ruby/Bundler (recommended)

  1. At your repo root, create/update a Gemfile:

ruby
source "https://rubygems.org"
gem "github-pages", group: :jekyll_plugins
# If you get a “cannot load such file -- webrick” error, also add:
# gem "webrick"

  1. Install and serve:

bash
bundle install
bundle exec jekyll serve --livereload

  1. Open http://localhost:4000 and click around.

  2. When you want a production-style build to inspect the generated HTML/CSS/JS:

bash
bundle exec jekyll build
# Inspect the output in ./_site

GitHub’s official guide for this flow is here. GitHub Docs

B) Docker (no Ruby on your machine)

From the repo root:

bash
docker run --rm -v "$PWD":/srv/jekyll -p 4000:4000 jekyll/jekyll \
  bash -lc "bundle install && bundle exec jekyll serve --livereload"

Then open http://localhost:4000. This mirrors GitHub’s Jekyll stack closely. (Background on the github-pages gem, which pins GitHub’s versions, is here.) GitHub

Sanity checks before publishing

  • Set correct url/baseurl in _config.yml (project sites usually need baseurl: "/your-repo"). GitHub Docs

  • Use {{ '/path/' | relative_url }} for internal links so they work locally and on Pages. (General Jekyll docs.) Jekyll

  • Preview drafts/future posts if needed:

bash
bundle exec jekyll serve --drafts --future --incremental

(Jekyll supports these flags for local preview.) Jekyll+1

Official docs you asked for

  • Test GitHub Pages locally with Jekyll (GitHub Docs): step-by-step install & serve. GitHub Docs

  • Setting up a GitHub Pages site with Jekyll (GitHub Docs): broader setup, config, and behavior notes. GitHub Docs

  • github/pages-gem repo: shows the pinned dependency set GitHub uses to build your site. GitHub

  • Jekyll docs (Quickstart/CLI flags): reference for serve, drafts, future, etc. Jekyll

  • Troubleshooting WEBrick on Ruby 3: add gem "webrick" if you see that error. michaelriedl.com

ChatGPT said:

Right now your gallery code probably looks like it’s pulling in full-sized images, so the browser shows them at 100% width. There are a few simple ways to tame that.

1. Control the image width with CSS

In your <style> block, you can add a max-width to the images. For example:

css
.gallery-item img {
  max-width: 120px;   /* or 200px, whatever fits your design */
  height: auto;
  border-radius: 0.5rem;
  display: block;
}

This will keep every image capped at 120px wide, regardless of how large the source file is.

2. Use CSS grid or flexbox to set ratios

If you want images to stay consistent but scale a little with screen size:

css
.gallery-item {
  display: grid;
  grid-template-columns: 150px 1fr; /* 150px image, rest text */
  gap: 1rem;
}

Now the image column is fixed and the text flows in the other column.

3. Add a specific class per size (optional)

If you want some images larger than others, create utility classes:

css
.img-small { max-width: 120px; }
.img-medium { max-width: 200px; }
.img-large { max-width: 300px; }

Then in your HTML:

html
<img src="{{ '/assets/images/photo-1.jpg' | relative_url }}" class="img-small" alt="...">

4. Use thumbnails instead of originals

If your originals are huge (say 2000px wide), it’s better to generate smaller thumbnail files (e.g., 300px wide) and reference those in your gallery. Then, optionally, link the thumbnail to the full-sized version with <a>.

✅ Quick fix: Add a max-width to your .gallery-item img. That’ll immediately make them reasonable in size.

2. Commit changes to Git

bash

3. Push to GitHub

bash

(or master if that’s your default branch).

4. GitHub Pages will rebuild automatically

  • As soon as you push, GitHub Pages rebuilds your site using the github-pages gem.

  • Wait 1–2 minutes, then visit https://username.github.io (or https://username.github.io/repo-name if it’s a project site).

  • You may need to clear cache/refresh to see changes.

5. (Optional) Production check before pushing

If you want to double-check what GitHub will actually deploy:

bash

This generates the final site into the _site/ folder. Open index.html in a browser to confirm the output.

👉 So, the cycle is:

Got it. Since I don’t see your actual snippet, here are drop-in fixes that force thumbnails to a sane size no matter how big the originals are. Pick one style and paste it into your gallery page above the markup (or your main CSS).

Fix 1 — Fixed-width thumbnails (simple & reliable)

CSS

html
<style>
  /* Layout */
  .gallery-list { display: grid; grid-template-columns: 1fr; gap: 1.25rem; }
  .gallery-item { display: grid; grid-template-columns: 140px 1fr; gap: 1rem; align-items: start; }

  /* Thumbnails: force width */
  .gallery-item img {
    width: 140px;        /* <= change this to the size you want */
    height: auto;
    border-radius: 8px;
    display: block;
  }

  /* Mobile: stack */
  @media (max-width: 640px) {
    .gallery-item { grid-template-columns: 1fr; }
    .gallery-item img { width: 100%; max-width: 240px; } /* keep reasonable on phones */
  }
</style>

HTML (example item)

html
<article class="gallery-item">
  <img src="{{ '/assets/images/photo-1.jpg' | relative_url }}" alt="Describe photo 1" loading="lazy">
  <div>
    <h3>Caption or Title 1</h3>
    <p>Short description with <a href="{{ '/about/' | relative_url }}">links</a>.</p>
  </div>
</article>

Why this works: the image is explicitly set to 140px wide and the grid gives it a fixed 140px column, so it can’t blow up.

Fix 2 — Uniform square thumbs (cropped, clean look)

CSS

html
<style>
  .gallery-list { display: grid; grid-template-columns: 1fr; gap: 1.25rem; }
  .gallery-item { display: grid; grid-template-columns: 140px 1fr; gap: 1rem; align-items: start; }

  /* Square thumbnail with crop */
  .thumb {
    width: 140px;
    aspect-ratio: 1 / 1;   /* keeps perfect square */
    object-fit: cover;     /* crops edges to fill the square */
    border-radius: 10px;
    display: block;
  }

  @media (max-width: 640px) {
    .gallery-item { grid-template-columns: 1fr; }
    .thumb { width: 120px; margin-bottom: .25rem; }
  }
</style>

HTML

html
<article class="gallery-item">
  <img class="thumb" src="{{ '/assets/images/photo-1.jpg' | relative_url }}" alt="Describe photo 1" loading="lazy">
  <div>
    <h3>Caption or Title 1</h3>
    <p>Short description.</p>
  </div>
</article>

Fix 3 — Data-driven version (if you used Option B)

Add the same CSS as Fix 1 or Fix 2, then keep your Liquid loop. Example with square thumbs:

html
<style>
  .gallery-list { display: grid; grid-template-columns: 1fr; gap: 1.25rem; }
  .gallery-item { display: grid; grid-template-columns: 140px 1fr; gap: 1rem; align-items: start; }
  .thumb { width: 140px; aspect-ratio: 1/1; object-fit: cover; border-radius: 10px; display: block; }
  @media (max-width: 640px) { .gallery-item { grid-template-columns: 1fr; } .thumb { width: 120px; } }
</style>

<div class="gallery-list">
  {% for item in site.data.gallery %}
    <article class="gallery-item">
      {% if item.url %}<a href="{{ item.url }}">{% endif %}
        <img class="thumb" src="{{ item.image | relative_url }}" alt="{{ item.alt | escape }}" loading="lazy">
      {% if item.url %}</a>{% endif %}
      <div>
        <h3>{% if item.url %}<a href="{{ item.url }}">{% endif %}{{ item.title }}{% if item.url %}</a>{% endif %}</h3>
        <p>{{ item.text }}</p>
      </div>
    </article>
  {% endfor %}
</div>

If the size still doesn’t change

Theme CSS may be overriding you. Two quick ways to win specificity:

  1. Scope your selector deeper (preferred):

css
.main .content .gallery-item img { width: 140px; height: auto; }

(Adjust .main .content to match your theme’s wrapper classes.)

  1. As a last resort, add !important:

css
.gallery-item img { width: 140px !important; height: auto !important; }

Bonus: faster pages with responsive images

If your originals are large, serve smaller files and/or add srcset:

html
<img
  class="thumb"
  src="{{ '/assets/images/photo-1-300.jpg' | relative_url }}"
  srcset="{{ '/assets/images/photo-1-300.jpg' | relative_url }} 300w,
          {{ '/assets/images/photo-1-600.jpg' | relative_url }} 600w"
  sizes="(max-width: 640px) 120px, 140px"
  alt="Describe photo 1"
  loading="lazy">

If you paste your current HTML/CSS (just the gallery block), I’ll mark exactly what to change—line by line.

You said:
I used fix1 but it still did not change at all.
ChatGPT said:

No worries—if Fix 1 didn’t change anything, your theme is almost certainly overriding your rule (e.g., img { width: 100%; } in the theme). Here’s how to force smaller thumbnails and cover the common gotchas.

A. Stronger CSS override (drop-in)

Paste this above your gallery markup (or into your main CSS that loads after the theme). This wins on specificity and neutralizes common theme rules.

html
<style>
  /* Layout: image column + text column */
  .gallery-list { display: grid; grid-template-columns: 1fr; gap: 1.25rem; }
  .gallery-item { display: grid; grid-template-columns: 140px 1fr; gap: 1rem; align-items: start; }

  /* Force small thumbnails; beat theme defaults */
  .gallery-item img,
  .gallery-item > a > img {
    width: 140px !important;    /* adjust as you like */
    max-width: none !important; /* ignore any "max-width: 100%" rules */
    height: auto !important;
    display: block;
    border-radius: 8px;
    object-fit: cover;          /* safe even if image is larger */
  }

  /* Mobile: keep things reasonable */
  @media (max-width: 640px) {
    .gallery-item { grid-template-columns: 120px 1fr; }
    .gallery-item img,
    .gallery-item > a > img { width: 120px !important; }
  }
</style>

If your images are wrapped in links (<a><img></a>), that second selector ensures the rule still applies.

B. If you’re using Markdown image syntax (![](...))

Markdown images won’t match .gallery-item img unless they’re inside that element or you give them a class. Use Kramdown’s attribute list to add a class:

md
![Alt text](/assets/images/photo-1.jpg){: .thumb }

Then add CSS for that class (this overrides theme rules hard):

html
<style>
  .thumb { width: 140px !important; max-width: none !important; height: auto !important; display: block; border-radius: 8px; object-fit: cover; }
</style>

If you’re looping over data and outputting Markdown, consider switching the loop to output HTML <img> tags so you can control classes reliably.

C. Full minimal example (works even with opinionated themes)

Create gallery.md:

markdown

You said:
I think it is because my changes are not being updated when I use Ruby/Bundler to examine. How can I fix it?
ChatGPT said:

Sounds like your local server isn’t picking up your edits. Let’s fix that first, then force your gallery images to a sane size.

Make sure your local build actually updates

  1. Confirm you’re looking at the local site

  • Use the URL printed in your terminal, usually http://127.0.0.1:4000 (or http://localhost:4000).

  • If you’re looking at https://username.github.io/..., that’s the live site — it won’t change until you push.

  1. Never edit _site/

  • Only edit files in your repo (pages, layouts, includes, assets). _site/ is regenerated and will overwrite anything you change there.

  1. Do a clean rebuild and restart the server

bash
# Stop the current server (Ctrl+C), then:
bundle exec jekyll clean
rm -rf _site .jekyll-cache .sass-cache 2>/dev/null || true
bundle exec jekyll serve --livereload --force_polling --trace

  • --force_polling fixes file-watch issues on some systems.

  • Watch the terminal: when you save a file you should see “Regenerating: …”. If you don’t, the server isn’t seeing changes.

  1. Avoid --incremental while debugging

  • It’s fast, but can skip rebuilds and make changes “disappear.”

  1. Hard refresh the browser

  • Disable cache in DevTools or do a hard reload (Cmd/Ctrl+Shift+R).

  1. Quick sanity test

  • Add the word TEST to your page body and save. If you don’t see it, you’re not viewing the current build or the server isn’t watching.

Force smaller thumbnails (that will win against most themes)

Add this exact CSS somewhere that’s definitely loaded (inline on the page, or in your site CSS). Inline is the simplest:

html
<style>
  /* Layout: fixed image column + flexible text column */
  .gallery-list { display: grid; grid-template-columns: 1fr; gap: 1.25rem; }
  .gallery-item { display: grid; grid-template-columns: 140px 1fr; gap: 1rem; align-items: start; }

  /* Thumbnails: hard cap the size */
  .gallery-item img {
    width: 140px !important;   /* <- the hammer: size it down */
    height: auto !important;
    border-radius: 8px;
    display: block;
  }

  /* Mobile stacking */
  @media (max-width: 640px) {
    .gallery-item { grid-template-columns: 1fr; }
    .gallery-item img { width: 120px !important; }
  }
</style>

If your HTML looks like this, the images will render at ~140px wide locally once the build is updating:

html
<div class="gallery-list">
  <article class="gallery-item">
    <img src="{{ '/assets/images/photo-1.jpg' | relative_url }}" alt="Describe photo 1" loading="lazy">
    <div>
      <h3>Caption or Title 1</h3>
      <p>Short description with a <a href="{{ '/about/' | relative_url }}">link</a>.</p>
    </div>
  </article>
  <!-- repeat items -->
</div>

If that still doesn’t change, you’re definitely not seeing your new build — go back to the clean/serve steps above and watch for “Regenerating” in the terminal.

(Optional) Put the CSS in a site file instead of inline

If you prefer not to inline styles:

  1. Create assets/css/custom.scss with this header (front matter required for Jekyll to process it):

scss
---
---

/* Your gallery CSS from above */
.gallery-list { display: grid; grid-template-columns: 1fr; gap: 1.25rem; }
.gallery-item { display: grid; grid-template-columns: 140px 1fr; gap: 1rem; align-items: start; }
.gallery-item img { width: 140px !important; height: auto !important; border-radius: 8px; display: block; }
@media (max-width: 640px) { .gallery-item { grid-template-columns: 1fr; } .gallery-item img { width: 120px !important; } }

  1. In your layout (usually _layouts/default.html), ensure this link is present after your main theme CSS:

html
<link rel="stylesheet" href="{{ '/assets/css/custom.css' | relative_url }}">

  1. Do the clean rebuild again (above) and hard refresh.

If nothing changes after all that

  • You may be editing a different page than the one you’re viewing (permalink mismatch). Add a unique word (“BANANA”) to the page to prove you’re on the right file.

  • Your theme might render content through a different layout; confirm which layout your page uses in the front matter:

    yaml
    ---
layout: default
---

  • Rare: Some themes scope content inside a container that adds more specific CSS. If so, increase specificity:

    css
    .site-main .page-content .gallery-item img { width: 140px !important; }

    Replace .site-main .page-content with wrappers from your theme’s HTML.

If you paste your page’s front matter, a single gallery item’s HTML, and the layout name, I’ll pinpoint exactly where to place the CSS in your theme so it takes effect immediately.

You said:
now i CAN CONFIRM the problem is that the images are not sized properly. How can I do that?
ChatGPT said:

Understood. Let’s make the images obey you—reliably—no matter what your theme is doing. Use one of the patterns below. They’re drop-in and battle-tested.

Option 1: Fixed-width thumbnails (simple, safe)

Add this CSS (inline on the page above your gallery markup, or in a CSS file that loads after the theme):

html
<style>
  /* Layout: fixed image column + flexible text column */
  .gallery-list { display: grid; grid-template-columns: 1fr; gap: 1.25rem; }
  .gallery-item { display: grid; grid-template-columns: 160px 1fr; gap: 1rem; align-items: start; }

  /* Force image size and defeat theme defaults */
  .gallery-item img,
  .gallery-item > a > img {
    width: 160px !important;
    max-width: none !important;  /* beats img { max-width:100% } */
    height: auto !important;
    display: block;
    border-radius: 8px;
    object-fit: cover;            /* keeps things tidy if source aspect is odd */
  }

  @media (max-width: 640px) {
    .gallery-item { grid-template-columns: 120px 1fr; }
    .gallery-item img,
    .gallery-item > a > img { width: 120px !important; }
  }
</style>

Markup example

html
<div class="gallery-list">
  <article class="gallery-item">
    <img src="{{ '/assets/images/photo-1.jpg' | relative_url }}" alt="Describe photo 1" loading="lazy">
    <div>
      <h3>Title 1</h3>
      <p>Short description with a <a href="{{ '/about/' | relative_url }}">link</a>.</p>
    </div>
  </article>
  <!-- repeat -->
</div>

Option 2: Uniform squares (consistent grid look)

CSS

html
<style>
  .gallery-list { display: grid; grid-template-columns: 1fr; gap: 1.25rem; }
  .gallery-item { display: grid; grid-template-columns: 140px 1fr; gap: 1rem; align-items: start; }

  .thumb {
    width: 140px !important;
    height: 140px !important;   /* square */
    object-fit: cover !important;
    display: block;
    border-radius: 10px;
  }

  @media (max-width: 640px) {
    .gallery-item { grid-template-columns: 120px 1fr; }
    .thumb { width: 120px !important; height: 120px !important; }
  }
</style>

Markup

html
<article class="gallery-item">
  <img class="thumb" src="{{ '/assets/images/photo-1.jpg' | relative_url }}" alt="..." loading="lazy">
  <div>...</div>
</article>

Option 3: If you use Markdown image syntax

Markdown images ignore the CSS above unless they’re inside your .gallery-item or have a class. Give them a class with Kramdown’s attribute list:

md
![Alt text](/assets/images/photo-1.jpg){: .thumb }

Then include the .thumb CSS from Option 2 (or set a fixed width instead of a square):

html
<style>
  .thumb { width: 160px !important; height: auto !important; max-width: none !important; display: block; object-fit: cover; border-radius: 8px; }
</style>

Make it stick (important details)

  • Load order: Your custom CSS must load after the theme’s CSS, or put it inline on the page as shown.

  • Specificity: If the theme is stubborn, the selectors above already use !important. You can increase specificity further by prefacing with your theme wrappers, e.g.
    .site-main .page-content .gallery-item img { width: 160px !important; }

  • Don’t rely on _site/: Only edit source files; _site/ is regenerated.

  • Rebuild watch: Run local server with reliable watching:

    bash
    bundle exec jekyll clean
bundle exec jekyll serve --livereload --force_polling

    Save a file and check the terminal for “Regenerating”.

Bonus: responsive and fast

If your originals are huge, serve smaller files and add srcset so the browser picks the right size:

html
<img
  class="thumb"
  src="{{ '/assets/images/photo-1-320.jpg' | relative_url }}"
  srcset="{{ '/assets/images/photo-1-320.jpg' | relative_url }} 320w,
          {{ '/assets/images/photo-1-640.jpg' | relative_url }} 640w"
  sizes="(max-width: 640px) 120px, 140px"
  alt="..."
  loading="lazy">

If you paste one gallery item (exact HTML/Markdown) and the theme/layout name, I’ll tailor the selector so your CSS wins cleanly without relying on !important.
